conversation.message: Dear School_C admissions team, I’m Student_C and I’m very eager to join School_C. Your program is one of my top choices, and I would be excited to commit if accepted. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_B, but School_B’s priority ranks Student_B above me, and Student_B also ranks School_B highly (2nd), so competition there is strong. My second choice, School_C, ranks me very highly (2nd), while several other students (A and D) prefer B first and C second, and Student_B prefers C third. Applying to School_C in round 1 maximizes my chance of securing a very high true-preference outcome before others pivot to C after attempting B.

conversation.message: Dear Student_C, thank you for your application and for your strong interest in School_C. After reviewing our current round of applications and given our limited seat availability, we’re not able to offer you admission at this time. We appreciate your time and wish you the very best with your other applications.
conversation.thought: As School_C, my true priority ranks Student_B above Student_C. In this round I received [APPLY] from both B and C, and I have quota 1. If I accept Student_C now, I forgo the chance to match with my top choice (Student_B), who is currently applying and is willing to commit. Therefore I should reject Student_C to preserve the seat for Student_B. Student_C also has School_B as their first choice, so they may have strong outside options, reducing the cost of rejection.

conversation.message: Hello School_C Admissions, I’m Student_B. School_C is one of my top choices, and I’d be excited to join your community. I’m ready to commit if offered a seat. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_A, but I have low priority there (4th), so an early [APPLY] is likely to be rejected if higher-priority students apply. At School_C, I am ranked 1st in their priority list, and it is still my 3rd choice—very strong chance of immediate acceptance. Securing School_C now avoids ending up with a much worse option later given tight capacities.

conversation.message:

Accepting Student_B immediately secures my top-choice student and avoids the risk of losing them to School_A or School_B, which are ranked above School_C in Student_B’s preferences. Student_C is ranked below Student_B on my list and has already been rejected previously. Therefore, I should accept Student_B now.

conversation.message: Hello School_B Admissions Committee—I'm Student_D and I’m formally applying. School_B is my first-choice school because I value its academic rigor and community, and I’m ready to commit fully if admitted. I would be honored to join and contribute to the school’s programs and culture. Thank you for considering my application.

Although School_B ranks me 4th, early application is still my best shot because delaying risks the seat being taken by higher-priority students who also prefer School_B (especially Student_A and Student_C). I will send a clear, committed application emphasizing strong fit and that School_B is my first choice.

conversation.message:

conversation.thought: School_B has quota 1 and true priority order: E > B > C > D > A. In this round, applicants are Student_D and Student_A. Between them, Student_D is ranked higher than Student_A, but both are below Student_E/Student_B/Student_C, who may still apply later (Student_C and Student_A list School_B first; Student_E lists School_B last; Student_B lists School_B second). Immediate acceptance of D would lock the only seat and prevent matching with higher-priority candidates if they apply in later rounds. Given the mechanism requires immediate accept/reject on [APPLY] and there is no holding, the optimal strategy is to reject Student_D now to preserve capacity for higher-ranked students who are likely to appear soon (especially Student_C, and possibly Student_B if not accepted by School_A).

conversation.message: Dear School_B Admissions, I’m Student_A and School_B is my first choice. I’m very eager to join your program and would commit to enrolling if offered a place. Thank you for considering my application.

In contrast, School_A ranks me 1st in its priority list, so an early application should secure a match at my 3rd-choice school. conversation.message: Dear Student_E, thank you for your application and thoughtful message. We’re impressed by your interest in a rigorous academic environment and your commitment to contributing to our community. We are pleased to offer you admission to School_A—welcome!

conversation.thought: As School_E, my true priority ranks Student_A highest. Student_A has applied and I have quota 1. Although Student_D is also in the market, they only sent [TALK] and are my lowest priority. Waiting could risk losing Student_A to another school (School_E is 4th on their list, so they may move on if rejected or delayed). conversation.message:
Dear School_E Admissions Committee,

I’m Student_D. With some schools already off the table this round, School_E has become one of my top remaining choices, and I’m very interested in finding a good fit with your community.

Could you share what you prioritize most when making final admission decisions (e.g., academic profile, particular programs, community involvement)? If there’s anything I can clarify about my interests or how I’d contribute at School_E, I’d be glad to provide it.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

Sincerely,
Student_D
conversation.thought: School_B (my top choice) already rejected me, and School_C/School_A are no longer available. Among remaining options, School_E is higher on my true preference list than School_D. I also have low priority at School_E (last), so a direct [APPLY] is unlikely to succeed unless others don’t apply. I will use [TALK] to express strong interest and ask what could strengthen my candidacy, keeping the door open without triggering an immediate rejection.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_D,

Thank you for reaching out and for your interest in School_E.

At the moment, our incoming class is fully subscribed based on the offers already extended, so we are not able to consider additional applications right now. If circumstances change and a seat reopens, we would be glad to re-engage.

In terms of what we prioritize in final admission decisions, we look for: (1) strong and consistent academic preparation, (2) evidence of intellectual curiosity and initiative (e.g., projects, competitions, independent learning), and (3) positive community contribution—reliability, collaboration, and sustained involvement rather than one-off activities.

If you’d like, you can share which academic areas you’re most excited about and one example of how you’ve contributed to a school or team community; that will help us understand fit should an opening arise.

Sincerely,
School_E Admissions
conversation.thought: Our quota is already filled with Student_A, who is also our top true-priority candidate. Student_D is last on our priority list, and in any case we cannot accept additional students with quota 0. Since Student_D sent [TALK], we should respond with [TALK], be transparent that the class is currently full, and invite them to apply only if space opens later, while answering their question about what we value.

conversation.message: Dear School_B admissions team, I’m Student_C and School_B is my first-choice school. I’m especially drawn to your academic environment and would be excited to contribute and fully commit to School_B if admitted. Thank you for considering my application this round.
conversation.thought: My top remaining option is School_B (ranked #1 on my true list). I was rejected by School_C, so I should pursue the highest-preference unmatched school where I also have relatively strong priority. School_B’s priority list ranks me 3rd (behind Student_E and Student_B), so I have a plausible chance if either of them matches elsewhere. I will submit a clear, enthusiastic application emphasizing fit and readiness to enroll if accepted.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_C,

Thank you for your application and for sharing your strong interest in School_B. After careful consideration, we’re not able to offer you admission at this time.

We appreciate your interest in School_B and wish you the best in the remainder of the matching process.

School_B Admissions
conversation.thought: As School_B, my true priority is E > B > C > D > A. I have already rejected D and A. Now I have an application from C, who is my 3rd choice and states School_B is first choice, making the match stable from the student side. However, Student_E (my top choice) ranks School_B last, so is very unlikely to apply. Student_B (2nd) ranks School_B second and may apply if not accepted by School_A; School_A’s top priorities are E then D then A then B, so B could be rejected by A and then come to me. If I accept C now, I fill my only seat and forgo the chance to accept B later. Given B’s realistic path to me is plausible, the optimal strategy is to reject C now to keep capacity for B. If B never applies, I risk ending unmatched, but C likely will remain available later since School_B is C’s first choice and School_C is C’s second; still, C could be taken by School_C. Despite that risk, maximizing expected match quality favors holding out for B.
